profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The John D. Dace papers contain a single transcribed letter from Dace, describing how he hopes Vicksburg can outlast the siege taking place at the time.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: John D. Dace was a Confederate soldier in the American Civil War. As of 1863 July 4, he was with his military unit in Tennessee, and it is unknown which unit he was a member of or if he survived the war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The John D. Dace papers contain a single transcribed letter written by John D. Dace. Due to numerous misspellings in the transcript, and probably in the original, it is unclear where and to whom he was writing. The only John D. Dace that can now be found was a member of the 10th Missouri Infantry, but the unit was never in Tennessee.

The letter describes how Dace’s brother is currently in Tullahoma, Tennessee, and how Vicksburg is currently under siege by the Union Army. Dace writes that he hopes that Vicksburg holds out. He would not have known that Vicksburg surrendered the same day he wrote the letter.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to the current round of processing, the John D. Dace papers were arranged in a single folder with no title or date. Currently, the collection is arranged in one series: I. Correspondence.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John D. Dace papers, Accession #385, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Paul T. Fisher. Released on 2020-10-29.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains a single letter from John D. Dace. This series is in good condition.
